Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Foundations of Two-Way Communication Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Two-way communication, where clients/parties A and B wish to exchange a stream of information, is a natural form of communication of great relevance in present and future wireless networks. Applications include two-way high data-rate tele-medicine, video-conferencing, the synchronization of data among terminals, and communication between a base station and clients. The investigator seeks to establish a fundamental understanding of how best to communicate two-way exchanges of information over networks, of immediate relevance as 1) communication is intrinsically a two-way endeavor but has mainly been treated as two one-way links, 2) new techniques have led to significant progress towards the elusive capacity of a network, and 3) recent results have shown that techniques which exploit the two-way nature of the data can outperform and differ markedly from straightforward extensions of one-way methods to two-way communications. The research will be integrated with practice and education through partnering with Motorola, existing UIC Women in Science outreach programs, and the investigator-led UIC Software-Defined Radio Lab.

The intellectual merit lies in the development of novel theoretical foundations able to explain, predict and analyze optimal two-way communication strategies over wireless networks. The investigator focuses on three integrated thrusts: 1) the introduction of a framework for two-way communications to understand two-way networks with and without relays under different channel models and assumptions on two-way adaptability, 2) the derivation of exact, and alternative performance guaranteeing capacity characterizations for increasingly complex subsets of the two-way framework, and 3) the determination of when separation is optimal and derivation of joint source-channel rate distortion regions for the transmission of correlated sources over noisy two-way networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research supported by this grant led to numerous advancements and discoveries in the area of two-way communications from an information theoretic perspective. While most data to be communicated is inherently two-way in nature (voice calls, up and downlink of cellular or WiFi networks), it is generally treated as two independent one-way streams of information. In this project we characterized the fundamental limits of communication if the two streams are considered jointly and each terminal is permitted to use adaptation or interaction (alter was it transmits at the current instant based on what it has received previously). In the first few years of this grant we obtained bounds on the capacity region (the largest set of rates one can reliably transmit at) of various two-way networks including the two-way multiple-access/broadcast channel, the two-way interference channel, two-way relay channels,  and the two-way line network. In the last few years of this grant we developed bounds on the error exponent regions for the two-way channel. Error exponents characterize how fast the probability of error of a channel decays with the blocklength, or number of times a channel is used. This provides a more refined understanding of how adaptation or interaction can be used to improve communication systems — while in some cases it cannot improve the number of messages that may be transmitted (cannot improve the capacity), it may dramatically affect how fast the probability of error decays to zero with the blocklength (the error exponent).

We considered error exponents for the first time in two-way channels and showed that interaction can indeed improve the error exponent over non-interactive (one-way) schemes, even if each channel is used to share data in one direction with feedback in the other direction.

This grant produced 5 journal publications and 18 conference papers. Results were presented in numerous international venues including 14 invited talks  and 1 tutorial on on two-way communications. This grant has partially supported the Ph.D. studies of six students in electrical engineering, three of which have graduated with Ph.D. degrees.
